THE_oldy

This is a rather long post but bear with it, as it will try to use logic to explain everything rather than refer to laws of science that you haven't had the chance to study, or refer to obscure quotes that truly need the context to get any unbiased significance. 
 
 Religion is a way of explaining our surroundings and environment; it is human nature to want to know. This curiosity normally helps survival as with out knowing about the world we could not function (eg. how would you eat if you didn't know about shops?). Normally an incorrect belief of the world would cause you harm or death (eg. Thinking that you have to eat dirt as apposed to going to the shops), and so wrong theories don't hang about for very long (as any one that knows them is dead). This is not always the case however. Theories that don't directly effect survival, such as how we came to be, or why we are here, can't be eliminated in this way. As a result religion has relieved that part of human curiosity for a very long time, and beliefs that didn't were ether forgotten for better ones or, ironically enough, evolved and developed to become more satisfying.
 
 However, extraordinarily fast developments occurred in three crucial areas, communications, society, and science. The expansions in science triggered new discoveries faster than religion was able to compensated and changed to incorporate such things, and thus convincing less people. The change in society was such that it enabled people to speak with out prejudice about these new ideas that differed from the common belief, and new communications spread these ideas around the globe and enabled many people to collaborate to further develop them.
 
 This revolution was fast enough that people were able to see back at what they had believed: theories that were impossible in newly discovered science and that had no proof. And given the opportunity to learn from other people's mistakes, many people committed to only believe what was shown to be true, rather than try to explain every thing straight away.
 
 And essentially that is the difference between science and religion. Religion will try to explain everything by creating a hypothesis and working backwards to find supporting evidence and science will try to find evidence and work forwards to a hypothesis.
 
 Unfortunately the religious method of finding answers is fundamentally flawed. Its "guess and check" method doesn't work as essentially there are infinite different possible explanations available to check and so the chances of coming across the correct one are effectively zero.
 
 Before I go any further I just want to clarify a few things. There are limits to what the human mind can comprehend, and so even basic logic is not provable. The next best option that must be taken is that we accept as fundamentals the most basic things our mind can comprehend. If you don't understand what I mean by this then don't worry because this paragraph is intended for people that have very philosophical counter augments that often lead no were.
 
 If I was to ask a religious person of a provable way that he found out about his belief he would have to say that he was told. If the person that told him was asked the same thing he would have to say the same answer. Now of course it can go back wards like that for ever, it has to go back to three "possible" beginnings: some one lied, some one was insane/delusional/ect, or there was divine intervention/ect. The later of course can be eliminated as it does not fit the provable criteria of the question, and at the same time defies provable logic. An understandable counter argument is that science is the same, that everything I know I learnt in science class - I was told. And the person that told me that was told, and so forth. But that's were the difference lies. Let's take the example of gravity: I was told how it works by my science teacher, he was told by his, and so forth. But when we go all the way back down the line we would get to Newton, and upon asking him how he found out about gravity he would probably talk about how the apple fell on his head, and he thought about it, ran tests, and so forth - basically he discovered this fundamental idea of gravity. And from this discovery more people have made more, and developed it. So if you were to ask me how I know my theories on gravity I could go about it by showing you the same experiments and logic Newton and his successors used prove it from the fundamentals I mentioned earlier. Science works towards an answer from the fundamentals and religion does not.
 
 Another way of explaining this is by examining the creationist theory. One example of a creationist theory is that an omnipotent being created the world and placed all the animals including humans on it. A branch of this theory is that he created the world, then the sun, then animals, then the people, and then the rest in that order. A different branch is that he created people before the animals instead, or maybe he created the rest of the world before the people. Maybe the omnipotent being had purple skin, or yellow, or was a flying spaghetti with pink and orange poke-a-dots - There are unlimited possibilities, each as viable as the last. The fact that we're here doesn't prove one creation theory over another or intelligent design at all - but at the same time nothing disproves these theories. If there were only limited numbers of possible theories the "you can't disprove it" argument would be viable. But as you can't disprove the infinite other possible theories that angle of argument is out numbered infinite to one.
 
 Many believe that the amount of factors that would have needed to be just right for humans to evolve, make the chances of it happening dismissible. But one needs a better understanding of odds before making this argument. Let me give an example. Say that the chances of a coin landing and balancing on the edge are 3 billion to one. I then run a test were I make 3 billion people flip one coin each. Now let's say that the most likely out come occurred - one person's coin landed on the edge. If he could not see the rest of the experiment that person would assume that he is special. But in the grand scheme of things it is nothing special at least one person was likely to get a coin to land on its edge. It is the same with Earth; it is nothing special in the big picture considering the incomprehensible amount if possible solar systems.
 
 In reality science doesn't argue that intelligent design cannot be true, it simply argues that it is not true as far as it has researched and beyond that science doesn't try to blindly guess from the infinite possibilities. Or though science doesn't give the upfront answers to everything that religion does, it can offer some thing that blind faith cant - the limited answers that are given are more of less true. And in conclusion when one must make the choice between religion and science, they have a choice between knowing no truth, and knowing some.
Peeling

Don't get me wrong, but I think your piece shows a remarkably naive understanding of society, sociology, religion, and science. For example, you say:
 
...as it will try to use logic to explain everything rather than refer to laws of science that you haven't had the chance to study, or refer to obscure quotes that truly need the context to get any unbiased significance.
Since you are discussing philosophy, the laws of science aren't really relevant to any explanations anyway.
 
Religion is a way of explaining our surroundings and environment; it is human nature to want to know.
I can accept that thought, but I'm not clear on how our environment differs from our surroundings.
 
This curiosity normally helps survival as with out knowing about the world we could not function (eg. how would you eat if you didn't know about shops?).
Oh, I don't know. Grow food in a garden, gather it from various wild sources, hunt game animals in the forest.
 
Normally an incorrect belief of the world would cause you harm or death (eg. Thinking that you have to eat dirt as apposed to going to the shops), and so wrong theories don't hang about for very long (as any one that knows them is dead).
But you are using the word theory incorrectly. Since part of your discussion purports to be about science, one might make the mistake that you are using the word "theory" with a scientific connotation. You are not. What you are talking about is folk mythology, not theory.
 
This is not always the case however. Theories that don't directly effect survival, such as how we came to be, or why we are here, can't be eliminated in this way. As a result religion has relieved that part of human curiosity for a very long time, and beliefs that didn't were ether forgotten for better ones or, ironically enough, evolved and developed to become more satisfying.
Again, you are talking about mythology, whether religious mythology or folk mythology. Primitive people attributed lightning to supernatural beings because they had no understanding of how such events could be natural. Thus, events that weren't understood and couldn't be controlled became the deeds of gods acting on whims or because sufficient sacrifices had not been performed.
 
However, extraordinarily fast developments occurred in three crucial areas, communications, society, and science.
Thankfully.
 
The expansions in science triggered new discoveries faster than religion was able to compensated and changed to incorporate such things, and thus convincing less people. The change in society was such that it enabled people to speak with out prejudice about these new ideas that differed from the common belief, and new communications spread these ideas around the globe and enabled many people to collaborate to further develop them.
There is some truth in that. Most people of faith don't have a problem with science. However, certain cultist views do cling to mythology as revealed, unchangeable truth.
 
This revolution was fast enough that people were able to see back at what they had believed: theories that were impossible in newly discovered science and that had no proof.
Bzzzzzt. I'm sorry. Wrong answer. Science doesn't prove. Science explains - like this. First an observation of some natural phenomenon that the observer doesn't understand. The observer proposes an explanation for the phenomenon based on previously known science (laws and theories), experience, and intuition (guesswork). This proposed explanation is called an hypothesis. The next step is to test the hypothesis. This is done by first making a prediction of some unobserved condition or phenomenon that must necessarily be true if, and only if, the hypothesis is correct. The final step is to devise an experiment to test the prediction by making the observed prediction. If the test has been stringent enough, the hypothesis may be called a theory. If the hypothesis fails the test, then the hypothesis is adjusted (with the added data from the test) or the hypothesis is rejected and a new one proposed.
 
 Of course, science is a human endeavor so that "the scientific method" is just a guide to how individuals proceed in doing science. However, science is always tentative, at least logically, and science is predictive.
 
And given the opportunity to learn from other people's mistakes, many people committed to only believe what was shown to be true, rather than try to explain every thing straight away.
And many people, because the pursuit of science can be difficult, instead decided to declare their mythology as the truth and to view everything else, including science, in that light.
 
And essentially that is the difference between science and religion. Religion will try to explain everything by creating a hypothesis and working backwards to find supporting evidence and science will try to find evidence and work forwards to a hypothesis.
You are confused. You are mixing "creation science" with religion. They are not the same. When religion is represented as scientific, the starting point is the desired conclusion. It isn't an hypothesis but is declared as the absolute, unalterable truth. Then evidence is selectively chosen (and twisted) that will support that conclusion. Evidence that does not fit is rejected as the work of evil.
 
Unfortunately the religious method of finding answers is fundamentally flawed.
At least we agree on that.
 
Its "guess and check" method doesn't work as essentially there are infinite different possible explanations available to check and so the chances of coming across the correct one are effectively zero.
But that's not even how "creation science", or any religiously motivated science works. There is no checking involved - what I mean by that is that answers are always ad hoc. It doesn't matter if there is a better explanation available that does not involve mythology and superstition, if observations can be made to fit the religious scenario, it is evidence. Again, there is no checking of facts, i.e., no testing, and of course, no predictions.

But the latter is exactly what some (especially in the U.S.) propose as science and truth.

My bet, religion. There are signs of religious practice that go back some 30,000 years to the Cro-Magnon. But science, except for the unusual glimmer of a few, never caught on until the last few hundred years. Just think of what you know about science and the scientists who were instrumental in developing the theory. Here's a few off of the top of my head and the year that each died.
 
 Bacon 1294, Copernicus 1543, Brahe 1601, Kepler 1630, Galileo 1642, Descartes 1650, Newton 1727, Ampere 1836, Ohm 1854, Faraday 1867, Maxwell 1879, Darwin 1882, Clausius 1888, Joule 1889, Curie 1891, Pasteur 1895, Boltzman 1906, Thompson (Kelvin) 1907, Planck 1947, Hubble 1953, Einstein 1955, Bohr 1962, Heisenberg 1975.
 
 But we've been waging wars and burning people at stakes going back much farther than that, all in the name of religion. Yeah. I think religion would come back first and delay the development of science for a few tens of thousand years.

But it took a lot longer to develop. My point was that only after about 5000 years of human civilization did empiricism as science develop. Religion, supernaturalism, and mythology trace back into prehistory. What we know as science didn't even begin to exist until the late 1500s and 1600s. Before that it was OK to do science like Aristotle did - no experiment, only thinking about a logical answer. Thus, heavy objects fell faster than light ones and any fool could tell that the sun orbited the earth.
 
 But science is more than an inner way of thinking. It is a process and a method for learning about the universe. It is called methodological naturalism. That is not to say the science asserts that nothing exists except what is natural. It says that science can't study the supernatural.

 Here's a good description of how talkorigins operates;
 
 http://www.trueorigin.org/to_deception.asp
 
 The whole thing is a good read, but I think these three paragraphs sum it up the best;
 
 
The bottom line to all this is that the fundamental concept of evolution is clearly a manifestation of a metaphysical-not a scientific-worldview and, just as with any other religion, the facts must continually be interpreted and adjusted to fit with this belief. 
 
 Essentially then, TO is a propaganda machine for philosophical naturalism using the more acceptable and palatable cover of methodological naturalism. Evolution theory is nothing but the scientific operational model to support this metaphysical position. 
 
 TO attempts to cover this point by stating that in their group they also have Christian and other religious evolutionists-people that believe in God, believe in a creation by a deity, but also believe in evolution (i.e., middle-grounders). TO employs this strategy to give its visitors a sense of universal appeal, i.e. that anyone, regardless of their beliefs, may subscribe to evolution. But again, exactly what evolution are they referring to? The one that says "things change" (this is science), or the one that says "that's how everything came to be" (this transcends science and is philosophical naturalism-a metaphysical position)? TO uses the two interchangeably.

Let me put it this way, Jorge Fernandez is using the logical fallacy of 'Ad homenin attack'. He isn't attacking talk origins, he is attacking the scientific method. 

 
 No, he's attacking the talkorigins method. The blending of philosopical naturalism with methodological naturalism. 
 
 
 
 
 He then repeats many 'creationist' claims that are basically been shown to be incorrect, such as the lie about the Second Law of themodynamics, the 'probablity' claim, the 'non-existant' primate claim, and many other claims that have been shown to be false over and over again. 

 
 "Basically" is the magic word - not thoroughly. Basically shown by and for those who oppose intelligent design. 
 
 
Here is a response to Jorge Fernandez's claims here
 
 http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/trueorigin/fernandez.html

 
 This response is predictable, here is one paragraph to examine;
 
 
Since the Talk.Origin archive does not seek to promote any specific religion or philosophy, naturalistic or otherwise, it would be inappropriate for us to alter our disclaimer to that suggested by Mr. Fernandez. In fact, it would be downright dishonest for us to do so.

 
 Now here is another page from talkorigins, as one of them describes his visit to the ICR museum;
 
 http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/icr-visit/linke.html
 
 He basically describes what he saw, with the following color commentary;
 
 
"There were about 20 spaces in the parking lot." 
 
 "(By the way, the curator of the museum was listening to Rush Limbaugh at the front desk)"
 
 "I listened to a mother describe to her daughter how the oceans dried up...."
 
 "One of the museum patrons commented....."
 
 "One woman walking by commented....."
 
 "His friend replied....."
 
 "Another person said......"

 
 What did any of these things have to do with a neutral description of a museum visit? He was simply trying to make it appear that most everyone there is stupid. Hardly someone who "does not seek to promote any specific religion or philosophy, naturalistic or otherwise". He clearly promotes naturalism, by using ad homenin.
 
 This was the best one;
 
 
The Rosetta Stone A mock-up of the Rosetta Stone was also in the room. The plaque next to it read: "Rosetta stone from near Rashid (Rosetta), Delta Egypt; 196 B.C....This inscribed stone slab was discovered in 1799 by..." Nowhere did the plaque indicate that this wasn't the ACTUAL stone. In fact, from the language it seemed that I was standing before the real thing. The museum had become quite busy, and as I wrote the above quote some people walked by and marveled that the ICR museum had this artifact. I was amused, but broke their hearts when I tapped on the hollow cardboard "stone" and indicated that it was just a photograph. 

 
 If the museum wanted people to think it was a real stone, wouldn't they put it behind some glass to keep wise ones like him from "tapping" on it? Maybe from the language it seemed to him like he was standing before the real thing is because HE"S the stupid one. 
 
 
 
and here is a response in the feedback section.
 
 http://www.talkorigins.org/origins/feedback/aug03.html

 
 From this link;
 
 
You seem to be doing something that a lot of people do, which is to confuse the theory of evolution with atheism. The focus of this site is biological evolution. Not atheism. Not the big bang. Not whether God does or does not exist. Biological evolution, which is the theory that all modern life forms are derived from a common ancestor through descent with modification. That theory doesn't say anything about the beginning of the universe, or even the beginning of the earth, it only deals with the natural history of life on Earth. The theory of evolution does not conclude with "and therefore there is no God". Your dispute is with atheism, not with evolution.

 
 He seems to be doing something that a lot of people do, which is to separate the common ancestor theory with atheism. What religion states that the supernatural created ONE life form on earth, then left, and let it all evolve natrually? None that I know of. What religion (worldview) implies that natural processes caused the first life form to appear on earth, then it all evolved naturally? Atheism, and, his philosophical naturalism.
trebor

"Ad homenin" means to attack the person instead of the argument. That's what you've done here.
 

 
 Not surprising, but you are totally incorrect. I pointed out what he did, and then gave examples. 
 
 

 No, he's attacking the talkorigins method. The blending of philosopical naturalism with methodological naturalism. 
 

 
 In other words, talkorigins doesn't blantantly say "we don't know and therefore god did it'?? How do YOU think science works?
 
 
 < snipping irrealvencies <
 
 

 
 He seems to be doing something that a lot of people do, which is to separate the common ancestor theory with atheism. What religion states that the supernatural created ONE life form on earth, then left, and let it all evolve natrually? None that I know of. What religion (worldview) implies that natural processes caused the first life form to appear on earth, then it all evolved naturally? Atheism, and, his philosophical naturalism.

 
 Well then, you are making the fallacy of assocating the scientific method with atheism. You also seem to be insisting that the creation stories must be taken literally. However, people of faith don't have to take the creation stories literally. There are a number of peopel who are christians say 'The bible teaches god created man'.. but view evolution as the way God created man.
 
 You seem to be taking your religious viewpoint at the only religious viewpoint.
 
 So sorry, but it isn't.
OccamsRazor

And essentially that is the difference between science and religion. Religion will try to explain everything by creating a hypothesis and working backwards to find supporting evidence and science will try to find evidence and work forwards to a hypothesis.

 
 
You are confused. You are mixing "creation science" with religion. They are not the same. When religion is represented as scientific, the starting point is the desired conclusion. It isn't an hypothesis but is declared as the absolute, unalterable truth. Then evidence is selectively chosen (and twisted) that will support that conclusion. Evidence that does not fit is rejected as the work of evil.

 
 I think you are splitting some semantic hairs with this response, and THE_oldy's point is quite correct in its general meaning. 
 
 Science says
 
 evidence-< analysis -< conclusion
 
 while religion says
 
 conclusion-< evidence-< analysis
 
 This is applicable to religion as a whole, and not just creation science. Beyond the material assembled in the Bible there has been no new "offiical" biblical material added since and so the same conclusions are applied ad nauseum throughtout history. Admittedly, every so often a group comes along who interprets a new "conclusion" but there is never really a change to the basic attitude with which religion treats the rest of the human experience. It comes first and has all the answers, everything else is secondary to its truth.
 
 Anyway, nice post THE_oldy, I very much agree with your line of reasoning. I'd like to ask what you think about the effect of religion as a mechanism for cultural unity- this must be the other important causative influence along side the need to be able to explain the "why" in a time long before an empirical understanding of the world was established.
pandion

I think you are splitting some semantic hairs with this response, and THE_oldy's point is quite correct in its general meaning.
OK. But I make a distinction between religion and "creation science" that you two don't seem to be making.
prschuster

Originally Posted by marc9000
 Atheism, (thinly disguised as science) creates the hypothesis that there is no God, and works backwords to find evidence for only that hypothesis.
 
 
 Trebor:
 Now, I have seen a lot of very stupid statements, but that one is pretty extreme. Science says absolutely nothing about the existance or non-exstance of god. Many scientists are religious. 
 
 
 
 Walking-fish:
 Isn't it frustrating to have to field that same old assertion time & again from creationists? The first time I came across that idea was in "Darwin on Trial" by Phillip E Johnson, a lawyer (surprise surprise). Since then the whole creationist movement has taken up his position that the distinction between philosophical & methodological naturalism (read materialism or atheism) is nothing but a smoke screen for evolutionists to hide behind. I can't remember how many times I've tried to explain the difference between not refering to God and "denying God", all to no avail. The funny thing (and I'm not laughing) is that, once evolution is marked as a fundamentally atheistic idea, the creationists no longer have to argue the evidence. They use this assertion to dismiss the validity of the very methods of gathering evidence, and all discussion ceases. In other words, the above statement effectively does away with any further dialogue, IMHO.
pandion

Walking-fish:
 Isn't it frustrating to have to field that same old assertion time & again from creationists? The first time I came across that idea was in "Darwin on Trial" by Phillip E Johnson, a lawyer (surprise surprise). Since then the whole creationist movement has taken up his position that the distinction between philosophical & methodological naturalism (read materialism or atheism) is nothing but a smoke screen for evolutionists to hide behind. I can't remember how many times I've tried to explain the difference between not refering to God and "denying God", all to no avail. The funny thing (and I'm not laughing) is that, once evolution is marked as a fundamentally atheistic idea, the creationists no longer have to argue the evidence. They use this assertion to dismiss the validity of the very methods of gathering evidence, and all discussion ceases. In other words, the above statement effectively does away with any further dialogue, IMHO.
I couldn't agree more. I have but one nit to pick. That is in the way that you equated some ideas. The way that you expressed it, one might think that you meant that philosophical naturalism was the same as materialism, and that methodological naturalism was the same as atheism. While philosophical naturalism may be atheistic, and while it may even be materialistic, methodological naturalism isn't. Methodological naturalism isn't a philosophy but, as the name indicates, a method of investigating nature. It is science. So unless creationists wish to deny that their god is supernatural, he/she/it is not a proper subject of study of methodological naturalism. Science neither affirms nor denies the supernatural nor the god of the creationists. Science doesn't examine that question - there are limits to what questions science can answer. Science doesn't deny any god since there has been no evidence of any god presented the can be quantified.
 
 Science is atheistic in the same way that plumbing is atheistic. Funny that I don't see creationists railing against plumbers.
prschuster

Pandion wrote:
 I couldn't agree more. I have but one nit to pick. That is in the way that you equated some ideas. The way that you expressed it, one might think that you meant that philosophical naturalism was the same as materialism, and that methodological naturalism was the same as atheism. While philosophical naturalism may be atheistic, and while it may even be materialistic, methodological naturalism isn't. Methodological naturalism isn't a philosophy but, as the name indicates, a method of investigating nature. 
 
 
 
 Walking-fish:
 Sorry for my awkward semantics. I was actually implying that it was the creationists who equate these three words in order to read Methodological Naturalism as a code word for atheistic materialism. That's why I put the phrase, "read materialism atheism", in parentheses. I've had too many (one is too many) arguments with creationists over this confusion. I've even been told that I'm essentially in denial of my own materialistic philosophy, when I claim I'm not a materialist, just because ... you guessed it ... I accept evolution. Does that clear up the communication between us?
pandion

That's why I put the phrase, "read materialism atheism", in parentheses. I've had too many (one is too many) arguments with creationists over this confusion. I've even been told that I'm essentially in denial of my own materialistic philosophy, when I claim I'm not a materialist, just because ... you guessed it ... I accept evolution. Does that clear up the communication between us?
Indeed, all clear. I too have been called a materialist and an atheist simply because I am a biologist, a methodological naturalist.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Differences of science and religion
